POST MORTEM
P from historic Annapolis, there came eleven gridiron warriors,
with 'a glint of defiance in their eyes and a passion for revenge
surging through their souls. NOt since 1?.17., had St. John's been able
to ,take the measure ,of a johns Hopkins ..football team. Year after
year, they had been forced to accept the borers',share. But,this year,
.under the direction of their coach, "Tody" Riggs, the JohnnieS came"
to town with a determined look on their faces and swore a fierce oath
that their past defeats would be avenged.
Out from the locker rooms, under the Homewood Field stands,
seyed Jays. Last week, they had made New Vick ,

gasp with amazeinerit-Wholding the powerful Columbia outfit to a
14-to-13 score. The newspaper experts had picked them to again beat
old St. John's. There was a confident spirit in their ranks as they.
carried on their preliminary work,out It looked like another Hop,
kills year.

the Jays got possession of the ball, the St. John's defenses held like
a mighty fortress. Hopkins was simply outclassed,-outguessed and

CONGRATULATIONS TO THE JAY
HEN the Black and Blue Jay announced a change in editorial
policy for the coming year, the snickers of the campus cynics
were heard on all sides. These chronic pessimists commenced to nudge
each other and smile: The Jay. they told each other, had always been
a glorified Capstans Billy's Whiz-Bang and could never be anything
else. However, with the first number of the rehabilitated campus
comic, the prophecies of the smart,alecks have failed to materialize.

W

The Jay staff may well be proud of their first issue. The editorial
copy is good, the illustratiorls are well executed, the typography is
excellent. The pages and pages of "he-she" jokes are, we are glad
to report, a thing of the past. In their places, are poems, stories and
articles of general interest.
Our esteemed colleague, Mr. Kolb, hammers his typewriter to
good effect and hurls several verbal brick bats at the once famous
Tudor and Stuart Club. Kolb's slashing denunciation certainly shows
the literary club in a had light. Perhaps, a couple of sticks of dynamite would awaken the literati from their drowsy lethargy.
The new Jay meets with our unqualified approval. To the staff,
we offer the heartiest congratulations and best wishes for continued •

father's family life were years of
unclouded happiness. My father
was busy writing and took an active
part in the education of his children.

children and managed' 'the large
home and was a secretary to my
father—a very difficult position....
as a matter of fact, she copied War
and Peace and Anna Karanina eight
times in all. Some things she had
to copy over a hundred times."

life, his ;eat period of moral difficulty, and the search for a satisfying religion.

"The great advantage the United
States has received front Bolshevism is that it has given us the 'eminent son of Tolstoy. That he has
become a thorough American can
best be.shown from his own words.
When I met him a little while ago
I said I should surely recognize him
from the portraits of his father to
which he replied "It cotslcle.lnly have
been I or one of the Smith Brothers
that made the cough drops." With
these words of introduction Dr.
Lancaster presented Count Ilya Tolstoy to a most appreciative audience
which crowded the C. E. Hall last
Thursday. The reference to *hirsute -adornment provoked _much_ applause..
• Hundredth Anniversary
"The whole world was celebrating
the hundredth anniversary of the
birth of my father this year. My
father was born September 18.
1828. It is hard for us to realize
the condition that prevailed in this
country and in Russia at that time.
They did not know matches or kerosene, there were no railways and
the telegraph and telephone had not
been invented, there were no automobiles. They were living in the
most primitive conditions. I ant inclined to think that-living in their
primitive way they were much more
happy than we are With our electricour telephones,--our poison gas.
My father was born underthe reign
of Nicholas I at a time When slavery
was a very common thing and men
and women were bartered for
horses or cattle, or a trained bear.
Soldiers were flogged to death in
the 'Army.

CONGRATULATIONS TO THE JAY
HEN the Black and Blue Jay announced a change in editorial
policy for the coming year, the snickers of the campus cynics
were heard on all sides. These chronic pessimists commenced to nudge
each other and smile: The Jay. they told each other, had always been
a glorified Capstans Billy's Whiz-Bang and could never be anything
else. However, with the first number of the rehabilitated campus
comic, the prophecies of the smart,alecks have failed to materialize.

W

The Jay staff may well be proud of their first issue. The editorial
copy is good, the illustratiorls are well executed, the typography is
excellent. The pages and pages of "he-she" jokes are, we are glad
to report, a thing of the past. In their places, are poems, stories and
articles of general interest.
Our esteemed colleague, Mr. Kolb, hammers his typewriter to
good effect and hurls several verbal brick bats at the once famous
Tudor and Stuart Club. Kolb's slashing denunciation certainly shows
the literary club in a had light. Perhaps, a couple of sticks of dynamite would awaken the literati from their drowsy lethargy.
The new Jay meets with our unqualified approval. To the staff,
we offer the heartiest congratulations and best wishes for continued •

"The first fifteen years of my
father's family life were years of
unclouded happiness. My father
was busy writing and took an active
part in the education of his children.
My mother cared for hew thirteen
children and managed' 'the large
home and was a secretary to my
father—a very difficult position....
as a matter of fact, she copied War
and Peace and Anna Karanina eight
times in all. Some things she had
to copy over a hundred times."

life, his ;eat period of moral difficulty, and the search for a satisfying religion.

"The great advantage the United
States has received front Bolshevism is that it has given us the 'eminent son of Tolstoy. That he has
become a thorough American can
best be.shown from his own words.
When I met him a little while ago
I said I should surely recognize him
from the portraits of his father to
which he replied "It cotslcle.lnly have
been I or one of the Smith Brothers
that made the cough drops." With
these words of introduction Dr.
Lancaster presented Count Ilya Tolstoy to a most appreciative audience
which crowded the C. E. Hall last
Thursday. The reference to *hirsute -adornment provoked _much_ applause..
• Hundredth Anniversary
"The whole world was celebrating
the hundredth anniversary of the
birth of my father this year. My
father was born September 18.
1828. It is hard for us to realize
the condition that prevailed in this
country and in Russia at that time.
They did not know matches or kerosene, there were no railways and
the telegraph and telephone had not
been invented, there were no automobiles. They were living in the
most primitive conditions. I ant inclined to think that-living in their
primitive way they were much more
happy than we are With our electricour telephones,--our poison gas.
My father was born underthe reign
of Nicholas I at a time When slavery
was a very common thing and men
and women were bartered for
horses or cattle, or a trained bear.
Soldiers were flogged to death in
the 'Army.
